specs/wallaby/replicated_volume_migratio.message: need a space before the parenthesis

This roughly what needs to happen, but you haven't described a way to do this.  At the midcycle, Gorka pointed out that a good way to do this would be to model something on the way snapshots are currently handled, namely, they go through the scheduler to find out if the operation will be allowed.  

These patches may give you some ideas:

Create snapshot: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/509011
Manage snapshot: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/538413

I don't understand your comment.  The REST API makes a call out to the volume api, where the check is currently being done.  The patches referenced above change code that is called by the REST API (you can tell because they have to add mocks to the REST API unit tests).  They change the code in the volume_api so that instead of calling the volume_rpcapi to do the manage existing snapshot, the code now calls the scheduler_rpcapi to handle it (see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/538413/3/cinder/volume/api.py).  What the scheduler manager does is check the backend to see if the operation can be satisfied; if not, it raises an execption; otherwise it calls the volume_rpcapi to manage the existing snapshot (see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/538413/3/cinder/scheduler/manager.py).

Gorka's suggestion is that you use a similar flow to determine whether it's OK to migrate a replicated volume or not.

Above snapshot related implementations are done at scheduler-level, where as in our case the call isn't coming out from API level itself because there is a proper check to restrict(replicated_Status : ENABLED) this operation.

Hi Brian, thanks for the comments. With reference to the (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/538413/3/cinder/volume/api.py) of manage snapshots, sharing my approach in the new patch where the decision to migrate a replicated-volume is taken basing upon the "replication_status" that we get exclusively from host service details(svc) in volume/api.py.

-1: Sorry, but based on the contents of this spec and the proposed patch I believe a lot more detail will be necessary here because:

The feature cannot be dependent on the operator setting things right in a volume type, support for this feature should be automatically detected by Cinder based on the drivers reported information, and this mechanism must be explained here, even if it's at a high level.

Cinder supports different types of replication, asynchronous and synchronous, and some drivers support only one of them, but other drivers support both depending on how the storage array has been configured and a cinder volume type can allow scheduling volumes to multiple cinder backends.

This means that if we have something like:
 - cinder with 2 backends (HPE's 3PAR and IBM Storwize) and both with replication enabled, but one synchronous and the other asynchronous

 - a volume type with a single extra spec: `replication_enabled` set to `<is> True`.

Then if we create a volume with this type it may land on any of these 2 backends, but let's assume it lands on the backend doing synchronous replication. Now if we request it to migrate to the other backend (which is acceptable since it's the same volume type), which is doing asynchronous replication, then when the operation complete there will be a period of time where the volume is not actually replicated and the operator may not be aware of this.

This is one of the reasons why it is currently disabled.

We also have to take into account that two pools from the same storage array may be configured as two different cinder backends, so it's not so straightforward to tell when it's the same backend.  This can probably be an acceptable limitation of the implementation (only work for multi-pool backends), but this must be spelled out in the spec and described how we are going to make sure that's the case.

This change will affect how the REST API behaves, so it will also require a new API microversion, which is not mentioned in this document.

That's why I believe this feature requires to carefully consider the different backends and detail how it's going to behave.

- With new approach we are not using the Extra-spec to decide whether the backend is capable of migrating replicated-volumes.

- In this approach we are making use of Backend Service details , which are updated during Initialization of backend driver.
- In service details we have the "replication_status" attribute of the backend.

Below are the details of volume service for one backend :-

svc - 
Service(active_backend_id=None,availability_zone='nova',binary='cinder-volume',cluster<?>,cluster_name=None,created_at=2021-06-07T07:23:58Z,deleted=False,deleted_at=None,disabled=False,disabled_reason=None,frozen=False,host='devstack@os2076-pool3',id=7,modified_at=None,object_current_version='1.38',replication_status='enabled',report_count=51,rpc_current_version='3.16',topic='cinder-volume',updated_at=2021-06-07T07:33:44Z,uuid='2ab67fef-f7ca-4b54-af16-889dae5c811e')

Below is the sample code in "volume/api.py" with new approach:-

        replication_status = svc.get('replication_status', None)
        if replication_status == fields.ReplicationStatus.ENABLED:
            expected['replication_status'] = (
                None,
                fields.ReplicationStatus.DISABLED,
                fields.ReplicationStatus.NOT_CAPABLE,
                fields.ReplicationStatus.ENABLED)

I fail to see how that resolves the issues I pointed out in my comment, as all it does is allow  the migration to be called, doesn't mean that there won't be a period of time when the volume is not fully replicated when changing from sync to async replication.

In any case, Active-Active deployments would need to be taken into consideration, as they would use the Cluster versioned object instead of the Service one.
Definitely impact, since we are currently rejecting it now.

work

Although bork might actually be right with how this would constantly be hitting the DB.
in the scheduler by changing it to

Does Cinder have a similar concept to 'claims' in the nova compute ResourceTracker? Doing those resource claims in the compute, post-scheduling, is also racy, especially for the CachingScheduler, and can result in several reschedule attempts to build a VM. Does Cinder have a similar concept to reschedules if a given storage pool is full and fails to carve out space for a new volume? Or does the request just end there with a failure?
We actually do reschedule since very long ago: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/stable/queens/cinder/volume/flows/manager/create_volume.py#L60-L208
I don't believe we do reschedules.  I think, however, if we are going to make changes to make the scheduler less racey we may need to do something like that to avoid being overly restrictive.

Alternatively, use Placement which is considered global to Cinder (like Keystone) and can be used to 'claim' resource allocations against providers (storage pools) atomically. See:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/pike/implemented/placement-claims.html

If you use Placement, you can eventually (hopefully at least) move some of the existing post-DB scheduler filters into Placement filters, so filter in SQL queries rather than in python, see:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/rocky/approved/placement-req-filter.html
I can work some of these if you'd like:)
Not really, not if they are single-node and you're just running a single c-sch process.

Patch set 22 disables ceph orch after ceph deployment and before overcloud deployment as an experiment to see if the presence of the orch causes Heat to fail.

If Heat succeeds then the deployment will get further but fail when standing up RGW because orch is necessary for that. One way to deal with that is to modify scenario 001 so it goes back to RBD only and we rely on 004 to test RGW and Dashboard (which require the orch). We should still be able to create pools if orch is disabled.

- The tripleo_create_admin role (which creates the tripleo-admin user for everything) failed [0] on one out of four jobs

- It failed on the "create user" task [1] which really just calls the ansible user module [2]

- When correlating the failed task time [3] with the journal log [4] I see "useradd[31970]: failed adding user 'ceph-admin', exit code: 9" [5]

- Exit code 9 means "username already in use" [6]

- The journal [4] shows "new user: name=ceph-admin" only once

- We're using  Ansible Version: 2.8.20 per the job output [7]

- The user module in 2.8.20 hasn't been updated in 3 years though the version 2.13 was updated last 3 months ago

This issue is something that only happens in standalone deployments as a result of not configuring the network first. In multinode deployments the network would already be configured and --network-file network_data.yaml would be passed to both `openstack overcloud ceph deploy` and `openstack overcloud deploy` and we'd have a consistent network source.

What's happening in this job is that I used an initial ceph.conf which has a side effect I'm taking advantage of because it results in the public/cluster networks not getting the default (192.168.24.0/24). This is basically a workaround which worked fine for RBD but we now see it doesn't work for RGW.

One solution is to pass an override which tells the overcloud to use the network the mon_ip is on as the storage network. I.e. I could create an additional environment file using the address from:

    hostvars[inventory_hostname]['ansible_default_ipv4']['address']

and override these with that address in an extra THT file:

    CephClusterNetwork: {{ _service_nets.get('storage_mgmt', 'ctlplane') }}
    CephMonNetwork: {{ _service_nets.get('storage', 'ctlplane') }}
    CephRgwNetwork: {{ _service_nets.get('storage', 'ctlplane') }}

OR I might prefer to configure a deployment with two networks:

192.168.24.0/24 all services
192.168.42.0/24 storage network

I'd then create a network_data.yaml file with the above two networks and pass it to both deployments with --network-data.

So the 42 network would be created by ansible in ceph-install.yaml outside of tripleo which would simulate the actions of networkv2.

I'm not sure though if standalone will work as desired when passed --network-data.

I'm doing this outside of the project and in the CI only since "real" deployments will use --network-data
Maybe though I should add a --heat-overrides list of key/value pairs
Using --network-data in standalone too

Yes, it's true the overcloud deployment does this, but WHEN does that modification of registries.conf happen? It happens _during_ overcloud deployment which won't help the ceph deployment as the ceph deployment happens before overcloud deployment and it also needs the container modification so it can pull the local image.

Now, you might ask, "is it a bug that we do this before the ceph deployment"? In normal circumstances, no because we have this:

  https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:bug%252F1958524

However, because we are hacking the registries.conf with the containers.yml [1] to use our local mirror, the resultant registries.conf is incompatible with the process above. Thus, in this job I pass --skip-container-registry-config because I modify it directly with these Ansible tasks.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Great work, thanks for making it easier to understand and adding uuid.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Could you elaborate?  Why does the fact that the CN is ignored mean that we have to remove the "organizations" field?

One implication I can see for now is that, k8s cannot get "group" info from the certificate, so if a Pod Security Policy is defined with reference to group "system:masters", the cert won't provide it. But so far we don't have such a policy.
I'm not aware of any policies that references "system:masters" either. Our default policies are very permissive.

My understanding here is that the CN field value is mapped to a user in the k8s RBAC for the authorization. Similarly, organization is mapped to a group. The documentation here says https://cert-manager.io/docs/reference/api-docs/#cert-manager.io%2fv1 that the CN value is ignored for the authorization if subject alt name is set. My initial understanding here was that the CN field value is being ignored as I changed organization=['system:masters'] (in v1alpha1) to subject:organizations:['system:masters'] (in v1) as all the deployment and daemonset pods were failing after "system kube-rootca-pods-update --phase=trust-new-ca" with the authorization error: 

Error from server (InternalError): Internal error occurred: Authorization error (user=kube-apiserver-kubelet-client, verb=get, resource=nodes, subresource=proxy)

Apparently for kubelet-apiserver communication needs user 'kube-apiserver-kubelet-client' to be authorized. If I remove subject:organizations:['system:masters'], I do not see this authorization error and all deployment and daemonset pods work as expected.

I'd like more of the above info to be in the git commit message for context for future code maintainers.

Are there any security implications from removing "subject:organizations:['system:masters']" ?

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message:
If organizations is specified, the 'commonName' is ignored?

Currently the default apiserver_kubelet_client_certificate from deployment has Subject as following:
 Subject: O=system:masters, CN=kube-apiserver-kubelet-client

With organization removed, will the certificate's subject has only 'CN=kube-apiserver-kubelet-client' as following?
 Subject: CN=kube-apiserver-kubelet-client

This is strange ... wrt CN is ignored, the document says "This value is ignored by TLS clients when any subject alt name is set", attention to "subject alt name" (SAN). Only when any subject alt name such as DNSs or IPs are set in SANs, that the CN will be ignored. But I don't see the default kube-apiserver-kubelet-client has any SANs.

yes, If the organization is removed from the code, certificate's subject has only  'CN=kube-apiserver-kubelet-client', like this,

Subject: CN=kube-apiserver-kubelet-client

 If subject:organizations is included in the code,  'CN=kube-apiserver-kubelet-client'  will be ignored during authorization which results into the failure of pods running, after the "system kube-rootca-pods-update --phase=trust-new-ca", due to the authorization error. At that time, the subject line in the certificate look like this,

Subject: O=system:masters, CN=kube-apiserver-kubelet-client

https://cert-manager.io/docs/reference/api-docs/#cert-manager.io/v1.CertificateSpec
Since this has been tested so I'll approve this change. I think we need to revisit this later on.

I tried again without removing organizations=['system:masters'], this is the error I get in the most of the pods logs after 'system kube-rootca-pods-update --phase=trust-new-ca'

Error from server (InternalError): Internal error occurred: Authorization error (user=kube-apiserver-kubelet-client, verb=get, resource=nodes, subresource=proxy)

If I remove organizations=['system:masters'], the error vanishes.

I might have confused certSANs with the fields under 'subject', but this is how the behavior is.

Similar question here, by specifying 'subject', 'commonName' will be ignored? The kubelet certificate will NOT have 'CN=system:node:controller-0'?

Currently kubelet certificate by default from deployment has the following subject:
 Subject: O=system:nodes, CN=system:node:controller-0

Even by specifying the subject:organizations[], certificate will have CN. i.e. certificate subject will look like this:

Subject: O=system:nodes, CN=system:node:controller-0

But CN=system:node:controller-0 will be ignored during authorization.

I thought the tests should mock out _is_native_multipath_supported to return False if they assume multipathing is not supported, Also do the tests actually run this on the system to find out if native multipathing is supported or not?

    with open('/sys/module/nvme_core/parameters/multipath', 'rt') as f:

roles/run-heat-tests/tasks/main.yaml.message:
actually this mixup of test is now becoming the complex things.

- tempest test which is branchless and as Tempest, heat-tempest-plugin master is used for stable branch testing, we needs to use master constraints.
- heat_integrationtests need stable constraints on stable branch which might not be compatible with master constraints (cinder v2 removal unhide this issue).

If we try to fix this issue by using the wallaby constraints for master Tempest and heat-tempest-plugins then it might create issue at any time.

IMO, best way is to separate these two tests run in separate jobs. one for heat_integrationtests which is basically branched can use stable constraints and second only run heat-tempest-test with master constraints (which are taken care by devstack).

I agree we should split out our tests not to mix up venvs but at this moment it'd be quite challenging to make that change in all branches. We might be able to try it in recent branches (wallaby and later ?) but that still requires some effort.

So I'd prefer we fix the issue by stable constraints (and pinning tempest if required) atm and consider more appropriate solution in master first.

This doesn't make a lot of sense to me.  It is a patch against a package source.  You should unpack the package source, create a git repo of it, then git am the individual patches onto it. OK, finally realized it's because change I999fc4aaf14cca02e4ed730afb844a043b59530c is not in ussuri. That change added the 'networks' kwarg to the _create_server call, which is required in microversion 2.74 (and since 2.37) [1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/api-microversion-history.html#id35

nova/tests/functional/libvirt/test_numa_.message:
Would it not be better to put

 api_major_version = 'v2.1'

here instead of in ServersTestBase? To limit the scope of the change?

Overriding in NUMAServersTestBase would not be enough. See the original proposal to fix this by adding the same thing to VGPUTestBase discussed here https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/822047/3/nova/tests/functional/libvirt/test_vgpu.py#228

I'm not suggesting adding anything to ServersTestBase, I'm asking if there is a reason not to override api_major_version = 'v2.1' in this class (NUMAServersTestBase) instead of changing the default for everything that derives from ServersTestBase?

For the details why it is needed please read https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/822047/4#message-f023edbce7be018e7486e7c59e076f2c083f89f3 tl;dr: without this the tests are using the v2.0 api without microversion support. v2.0 is a _very_ old API (microversions are added in Kilo). So I consider using v2.0 as a bug itself that was fixed in newer branches during a refactor but not here.

If it considered cleaner then I can propose a separate commit adding api_major_version = 'v2.1' to the ServersTestBase. But I would like to make that change happen as not using the microversion aware API in these tests feels very dangerous to me.
Thanks. I had trouble understanding this issue, apologies for making you repeat things you explained in earlier PS.
note: this is another change compared to original patch, and needed because we need to use in ussuri the self.start_computes() instead of the self.start_compute().

I think the real reason is a bug in the normal api client (self.api) definition of these test. It is coming from [1] and it requests an old v2 api client instead of the proper v2.1 api client. The v2 client does not understand microversions, and therefore the host forcing code change in the integrated_helpers cannot request 2.74. 

I think it is better to bump the api client to v2.1 in the base class in [1]. 

You are correct that in victoria this problem is not visible as the code in [1] is dissolved by some refactoring.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/184a3c976faed38907af148a533bc6e9faa410f5/nova/tests/functional/test_servers.py#L68

The patch-backs for the other versions did not require this due to [1], which changes the API version on the base class, but is not present in Ussuri. Figured it would be less risky for this change to update the versions directly in the classes that specified the host on the create requests.

For the details why it is needed please read https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/822047/4#message-f023edbce7be018e7486e7c59e076f2c083f89f3 tl;dr: without this the tests are using the v2.0 api without microversion support. v2.0 is a _very_ old API (microversions are added in Kilo). So I consider using v2.0 as a bug itself that was fixed in newer branches during a refactor but not here.

deployment/cinder/cinder-backup-pacemake.message: Are you missing the CinderCommon config_settings?
CinderBackupBase config_settings already includes CinderCommon config_settings so we don't need to include that agan here.

deployment/cinder/cinder-common-containe.message: Why not include these in cinder_common_volumes (after L27)?

The reason why I didn't include this in cinder_common_volumes is that the cinder_common_volumes is also used in CinderApi resource.

Since we have separated logging resource for api and the other services. IMO we shouldn't add something from OS::TripleO::Services::Logging::CinderCommon to CinderApi resource.

OK, that makes sense. This whole "cinder common" concept was introduced to avoid duplicating content in multiple files (where things often got out of sync, for example between the pacemaker and non-pcmk templates). But I recognize the fact that determining whether something is "common" is not always a simple yes/no decision.

I really don't understand the reason for changing "common" to "daemon" in all the template outputs. We chose "common" precisely because it conveys the notion that that they're common. In this context, the word "daemon" doesn't convey anything like that.
Thank you for understanding. Common simply means "typical," and isn't meant to mean "universal with no exceptions."

The reason why we renamed these items is that they are not actually "common". We don't use these items for api but only for the other services, thus I renamed it to "deamon" to explicitly shows that this is not used for api.
But maybe we can just rename this back to common regarding the fact that we use Cinder"Common" for the logging resource which is only used for daemon services...

deployment/cinder/cinder-scheduler-conta.message:
I don't think this resource is necessary when all the necessary pieces are already present via the CinderCommon resource at L72.

Until now, the CinderCommon resource was used by cinder-volume and cinder-backup, and I like the way you enhanced it to facilitate configuring c-vol and c-bak logging. I think the same technique can be used to configure c-sch's logging without the need to define another resource (L56).

I don't think this is necessary because the value is null for both file and stdout.

And if some config_settings were required, they should be accessed via the CinderCommon resource so that c-vol, c-bak and c-sch all work the same way (yes, c-api is unique).

I'd prefer to keep this because

1. It is consistent with the existing templates like nova-scheduler-container-puppet.yaml

2. It would be helpful to have the interface because we can easily implement parameters which become required in the future.
I guess I'm OK with keeping it for a future need, but I don't see where it's pulled in for the c-vol and c-bak services. This is how I realized it may not be necessary.
The CinderLogging resource at L56 could be eliminated by switching this to "get_attr: [CinderCommon, cinder_common_cmd_extra_args]"
Could [CinderLogging, volumes] be automatically included in [CinderCommon, cinder_common_volumes] ?
We shouldn't merge that into cinder_common_volumes because it affects CinderApi resource. I added another output key for CinderCommon to replace this.
I think it would be find to use [CinderCommon, cinder_common_host_prep_tasks], which already includes the CinderLogging's host_prep_tasks.

deployment/cinder/cinder-volume-containe.message: OK fine, except I think they're missing in the pcmk version of the template.

deployment/cinder/cinder-volume-pacemake.message: Don't you also need the settings from CinderCommon?
That is included via CinderBase config_settings, so we don't need to include it explicitly here.
Ah yes, I see that now, thanks.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Why does this happen? If umask is built-in should it not run without fail? I'm confused

See this document about running built-ins in puppet exec:
https://puppet.com/docs/puppet/7/types/exec.html#exec-provider-posix

On CentOS, umask is in PATH, so it works without shell as provider:
[root@controller-0 testing(keystone_admin)]# which umask
/usr/bin/umask

But on Debian, umask is not in PATH so puppet can't find it.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Basically "umask" is not an executable (on Debian it is part of the shell),  so in order for this to work, we need to be explicitly indicate that we are using the shell

there should be set -o pipefail also this could be done with simple command like

ps -Leaf | awk '/nova_libvirt_launcher.sh/ {print $2; exit}'

Thanks Sergii for your feedback.

The original command should work too, and in most cases it does. But we found a node where, for some reason, the command returns by mistake two PIDs concatenated, so the validation fails there.

We couldn't find the cause of that behavior, but with the proposed change it worked there.

Here is the output of the command directly in the node for the 3 options:
[heat-admin@overcloud-computeovsdpdk-0 ~]$ ps -Leaf | awk '/nova_libvirt_launcher.sh/ {print $2; exit}'
21500
[heat-admin@overcloud-computeovsdpdk-0 ~]$ ps -Leaf | grep nova_libvirt_launcher.sh | grep -v pts -m 1 | awk '{print $2}'
21500
[heat-admin@overcloud-computeovsdpdk-0 ~]$ ps -Leaf | grep nova_libvirt_launcher.sh | grep -v pts | awk '{printf "%s", $2}'
21500
It may need some investigation and improvement which can be done as follow up patch. I am removing my -1 there.

Yes, I think you are right here. We wont need it. Removed.
recommend testcase to force (another upgrade script to fail) multiple upgrade-activate runs so that the script must be able to support being run multiple times and not receive false failure.

I was wrong here. I initially thought, we can run this script during either migrate or activate action. Although, script runs successfully(even during re-run) and updates kubeadm configmap object, these updates do not get applied to the kube-apiserver pod/process. In this case, we will need to run 'kubeadm init' once again for these updates to get reflected. For new feature-gates to get applied, the script should be run during ansible bootstrap. So the correct action here is 'migrate' and not 'activate'. Let me know if I should do any additional checks with respect to action 'migrate' (N+1 side). Script re-run does not end up in a false failure during whichever phase it runs.
As the migrate stage may differ on DX, please also run platform upgrade from N-1 release running 1.21.8 to this release on AIO-DX/Duplex controller system with worker nodes
updating CR pending AIO-DX/Duplex platform upgrades integration

controllerconfig/controllerconfig/upgrad.message: Do we also want to remove "TTLAfterFinished=true" since it defaults to true as of K8s 1.21?

ValueError can happen if call this with wrong value_type, for instance:

Traceback (most recent call last):

Traceback (most recent call last):

Another concern is that there might be a task to install any packages during host prep tasks, which might be executed before this but I need to go through the all tasks implemented in host_prep_tasks.

It *may* have issues for update/upgrade. Or "just" update, upgrade implies a complete cleaning of the containers, as well  as, if I'm not mistaken, a reboot.

We don't have container startup during host_prep_tasks. So yeah... update MAY be at risk, it's something I overlooked :/. I may have to create a follow-up. Though moving that task to the rhsm itself may be "weird", since it's due to containers... Meh.
After discussion with Tengu++, we noticed host_prep_tasks should be executed before launching any containers, so this should not be a problem.
just checked: unregistered rhel9 does have the /etc/rhsm; it's created by subscription-manager, and that one is, of course, installed in the base. Sooo... I think we're all good?

It shouldn't be an issue. on a unregistered RHEL, /etc/rhsm should exist. This is also why I ensure we're on an actual RHEL, and not "some other distro from the same family".

As said, the main concern right now is "what about updates"... Though it SHOULD be fine, since an update won't move from 8 to 9 (that's an upgrade) and osp-17 isn't out yet.

> Another concern is that there might be a task to install any packages during host prep tasks, which might be executed before this but I need to go through the all tasks implemented in host_prep_tasks.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/roles_data.yaml#L166-L169

Why this check? Isn't it specific to all podman[1] which is the only container cli we support.

[1] https://github.com/containers/podman/issues/6192
OK, not to use with centos.

This would make rhsm to think that we're running it in a container (Though now also it assumes to be running in a container but not able to find rhsm.conf). Super side effect of mounting /var/run for containers:/

Yeah. I can't call this a "fix", more a workaround. Note, before EL9, it wasn't an issue, because subscription-manager didn't override the repository list... But now, it's an actual thing, and apparently we won't get anything from candlepin maintainers. We can't drop the /run:/run yet, and probably never will. Sooo... Meh.

I'll follow up as soon as I get another possibility. Note, there actually IS another way, but it's not really usable within OSP: exporting a specific env var makes subscription-manager drop the container check[1]. I tried it, but without any success :(.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: this is a sysfs coupling. Instead we should add the necessary information the the PciDevice object via the virt driver and simply read from that object here.

well, I could argue on this conditional by saying I don't like to have optional keys in a dict, and I'd rather prefer to have nullable values (or any other flag saying this is unset) but meh, all of the above does this already :-)

the binding profile is owned by nova.
or at least the feild is defiend as being used to pass info form the compute backend to the network backend

so nuetron in generaly shoudl not add keys too it and its an admin only field which operators are not ment to modify.

there is only one usage of this that is not drive by nova which is for the trusted vf feature and that shoudl be ported to a neutron network extesntiosn eventually.

https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/api/definitions/portbindings.py#L31-L34=

"""# The profile will be a dictionary that enables the application running
# on the specific host to pass and receive vif port specific information to
# the plugin.
PROFILE = 'binding:profile'
""""

its phrased that way since application running on the specific host can be nova, ironic or zun.


but each such applciation can more or less assume they have full ownership fo the port profile filed.

i would consider adding unused keys with a null value to be an anti pattern and i do not think we shoudl do that.

its an anti patther as its increaseing the data that we send over the wire and it woudl be contreay to all other usage of this field.

the established workflow is to only define keys if the value shoudl be used.

e.g. we dont define the pci_slot key for non sriov ports.

We can start fixing it by first creating some description about what is the expected / allowed structure of the profile in Neutron. Looking at the Neutron code[1] passing device_mac_address=None would not cause any trouble.

In the other hand we explicitly remove keys from the profile when the port in unbound. So I think not having the key is pretty normal.

I will keep this as is now.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/829247/11/neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py#776

nova/network/neutron.py.message: this is a wrong sysfs dependency. We should instead extend the PciDevice object with the necessary data.

We agreed on device_mac_address with Bence

No, these changes are still pretty open, especially due to the request from neutron team to add an api extension for it in neutron. So I happy to bikeshed around the naming. I'm wondering if stating that this MAC is the MAC of the physical device / MAC of the device backing the port would also be useful. Also "request" only useful if the reader knows that this field is set by nova, so the requester is Nova. I'm wondering how to encode all these information in not too long name.
